title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection (SSIFS) extension Stochastic Search Variable Selection (George McCulloch 1993) identifying inconsistencies Network Meta-Analysis (NMA). SSIFS two-step method, first step inconsistency factors specified, second step, variable selection inconsistency factors performed using SSVS method.

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: inverse-variance random-effects NMA model adjusted include \(\ell =1, 2, \ldots, p\) inconsistency factors described following equation \[ \boldsymbol{y = X\mu + \beta +bZ + \epsilon}, \quad \boldsymbol{\epsilon} \sim N(\boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{\Sigma} ) \quad \quad \boldsymbol{\beta} \sim N(\boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{\Delta})\] \(\boldsymbol{y}\) denotes treatments effect, \(\boldsymbol{X}\) design matrix, \(\boldsymbol{\mu}\) underlying basic contrasts, \(\boldsymbol{\beta}\) normally distributed random effects, \(\boldsymbol{b}\) effect inconsistency factors, \(\boldsymbol{Z}\) inconsistency factor’s index matrix, \(\boldsymbol{\epsilon}\) normally distributed sampling errors. Correlation matrix \(\boldsymbol{\Delta}\) block diagonal matrix, assuming common heterogeneity across treatment comparisons, covariance matrix \(\boldsymbol{\Sigma}\) assumed known obtained data based Franchini et al. (2012). Matrix \(\boldsymbol{Z}\) contains elements values 1, -1 0, indicating comparisons inconsistency factor added. Among choices may considered specification \(\boldsymbol{Z}\) matrix Lu Ades model (Lu Ades 2006), design--treatment model (Higgins et al. 2012), random-effects implementation design--treatment model (Jackson et al. 2014).

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: SSIFS effect inconsistency factor \(\ell\) described mixture two normal distributions, can written \[b_{\ell} | \gamma_{\ell} \sim (1-\gamma_{\ell}) N(0, \psi_{\ell}^{2}) + \gamma_\ell N(0, c^{2}\psi_\ell^{2})\] \(b_{\ell}\) effect inconsistency factor, \(\gamma_{\ell}\) auxiliary variable indicating inconsistency factor included NMA model, \(c\), \(\psi_{\ell}\) tunning parameters controlling mixing ability method. matrix notation SSIFS written \[\boldsymbol{b | \gamma} \sim N( \boldsymbol{0}, \boldsymbol{D_\gamma R D_\gamma} ) \] \[ \boldsymbol{D}_{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}=   \begin{pmatrix}     a_1 \psi_1 & 0 & \dots & 0 \\     0 & a_2 \psi_2 & \dots & 0 \\     \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \\     0 & 0 & \dots & a_\text{p} \psi_\text{p}   \end{pmatrix}   ,\qquad a_\ell= \begin{cases}   1, \quad \gamma_\ell=0\\   c, \quad \gamma_\ell=1   \end{cases}. \] Matrix \(\boldsymbol{R}\) denotes prior correlation inconsistency factors. can assume inconsistency factors independent setting \(\boldsymbol{R} = \boldsymbol{}\), can assume dependency inconsistency factors using Zellner g-prior described bellow \[\boldsymbol{R}=g \boldsymbol{ (Z^{'}Z) } \sigma^{2}, \quad \pi (\sigma^{2} ) \propto \frac{1}{\sigma^2}.\] specification parameter \(g\), unit information criterion (Kass Wasserman 1995) used, translates SSIFS total number observed comparisons network. Prior inclusion probabilities inconsistency factors specified \[\gamma_\ell \sim Bernoulli(1 - \pi_{con}^{ \frac{1}{p}}),  \quad \ell = 1, 2, \ldots, p\] \(\pi_{con}\) probability consistent network reflects prior believes likely consistent network. review 201 networks, 44 networks found globally inconsistent (Veroniki et al. 2021). Thus, \(\pi_{con} \sim Beta(157, 44)\) proposed.

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: Tunning crucial SSIFS order ensure good mixing method. Ideally, effect inconsistency factor included NMA model lie area close zero, far away area included NMA model. Regarding parameter \(c\), values 10 100 usually perform well cases (George McCulloch 1993; Perrakis Ntzoufras 2015). Possible values parameter \(\psi_\ell\) obtained pilot MCMC run NMA model standard deviation inconsistency factors.

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: properly tunning parameters \(c\) \(\psi_\ell\), difference direct indirect evidence practical significance (say \(\omega\)) can defined. Thus, inconsistency factor coefficient larger \(\omega\) absolute values (\(|b_{\ell}| > \omega\)), included NMA model (\(\gamma_\ell = 1\)). case \(\boldsymbol{R = }\), inconsistency factor higher probability included NMA model \[|b_\ell |> \psi_\ell \sqrt{\xi(c)}, \quad \xi(c) = \frac{2c^2 \log{c}}{c^2 -1}.\] example, difference 0.2 considered important, one possible parameterization set \(c = 10\) \(\psi_\ell = \frac{0.2}{\sqrt{\xi(10)}} \approx 0.1.\)

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: Inconsistency SSIFS evaluated examining posterior inclusion probabilities inconsistency factors, posterior model probabilities, posterior model odds Bayes factor consistent NMA model inconsistent NMA model.

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: Posterior inclusion probabilities estimated average times inconsistency factor included NMA model MCMC draws. Estimates 0.5 indicates local inconsistency, cause global inconsistency network.

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: Posterior model odds obtained ratio posterior model probabilities estimated \[f\hat{(m|\boldsymbol{y})}=\frac{1}{M-B} \sum_{t=B+1}^{M}{(m^{(t)}=m)}, \quad m(\boldsymbol{\gamma})=\sum_{\ell = 1}^{p}{\gamma_\ell 2^{\ell-1}}\] \(M\) number MCMC iterations, \(B\) burn-period \(m^{(t)}\) model indicator transforms \(\boldsymbol{\gamma}\) unique decimal number. examined posterior odds consistent NMA model (\(m(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) = 0\)) inconsistent NMA models, can evaluate consistency assumption. Also, comparison consistent NMA model (\(m(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) = 0\)) observed inconsistent NMA models (\(m(\boldsymbol{\gamma}) \ne 0\)), indicates NMA model globally consistent.

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: can install development version ssifs like :

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: ssifs requires contrast-based data used network meta-analysis. Also, multi-arm studies, possible comparisons must provided. case network disconnected, ssifs keeps studies belong largest sub-network order maintain one connected network.

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: Load brief alcohol intervention dataset ssifs package. dataset published network meta-analysis (Seitidis et al. 2022; Hennessy et al. 2019) contains 37 studies evaluating comparative effectiveness brief alcohol interventions preventing hazardous drinking college students. Prepare data ssifs. Run ssifs function, using AO-CT reference intervention. function default specification matrix \(\boldsymbol{Z}\) uses design--treatment model. can use Lu & Ades model setting argument method = "LuAdes", random-effects implementation design--treatment model setting method = "Jackson". Also, function default specifies correlation matrix \(\boldsymbol{R}\) using Zellner g-prior. can assume inconsistency factors independent setting argument zellner = FALSE. Regarding prior inclusion probabilities, function assumes \(\pi_{con} \sim Beta(157, 44)\) (argument rpcon = TRUE). setting argument rpcon = FALSE can set probability \(\pi_{con}\) fixed. rpcon = FALSE, function assumes \(\pi_{con} = 0.5\). can change probability argument pcons.
code: library(ssifs) data("Alcohol", package = "ssifs") TE <- Alcohol$TE seTE <- Alcohol$seTE study <- Alcohol$studyid treat1 <- Alcohol$treat1 treat2 <- Alcohol$treat2 set.seed(12) m <- ssifs(TE = TE, seTE = seTE, studlab = study, treat1 = treat1, treat2 = treat2, ref = "AO-CT")

previous_headings: Model Implementation through siffs > Detection of inconsistency
title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: Posterior inclusion probabilities can obtained like : first two columns refers comparisons inconsistency factors added. example, first row refers inconsistency factor added comparisons interventions Alc101 BASICS, obtained two-arm studies compare interventions. fifth row refers inconsistency factor added comparison interventions AO-CT AlcEdu, obtained multi-arm studies compare interventions AO-CT, AlcEdu e-CHUG. Column PIP refer posterior inclusion probability, columns b, b.lb b.ub inconsistency factors effect estimates corresponding 95% credible interval. method = "LuAdes", column Design NA. Lu & Ades model accounts loop inconsistencies. example, posterior inclusion probabilities suggest network globally locally consistent, since significant local inconsistencies causes global inconsistency network (posterior inclusion probabilities \(\approx 0 < 0.5\)). Also, note corresponding effect estimates significant close zero.
code: m$Posterior_inclusion_probabilities #>            Comparison            Design    PIP       b    b.lb   b.ub #> 1     Alc101 ; BASICS      Alc101BASICS 0.0221  0.0002 -0.1490 0.1464 #> 2      AO-CT ; Alc101       AO-CTAlc101 0.0222  0.0011 -0.1098 0.1518 #> 3     e-CHUG ; BASICS      e-CHUGBASICS 0.0234 -0.0007 -0.1738 0.1423 #> 4  Active-CT ; THRIVE   Active-CTTHRIVE 0.0236 -0.0025 -0.2077 0.1106 #> 5      AO-CT ; AlcEdu AO-CTAlcEdue-CHUG 0.0237  0.0018 -0.0992 0.1671 #> 6      AO-CT ; e-CHUG AO-CTAlcEdue-CHUG 0.0216  0.0015 -0.1069 0.1623 #> 7      AO-CT ; e-CHUG AO-CTe-CHUGBASICS 0.0237 -0.0013 -0.1443 0.1080 #> 8      AO-CT ; BASICS AO-CTe-CHUGBASICS 0.0232  0.0034 -0.0882 0.1957 #> 9      AO-CT ; AlcEdu AlcEduAO-CTAlc101 0.0227 -0.0027 -0.1424 0.0662 #> 10     AO-CT ; Alc101 AlcEduAO-CTAlc101 0.0219  0.0016 -0.0998 0.1475

title: An introduction to the Stochastic Search Variable Selection method using the ssifs package
text: posterior model odds can obtained like : Column IFs refers model observed MCMC draws (Inconsistency factors separated symbol ,), Freq refers number times model observed MCMC draws, f(m|y) denotes posterior model probability PO_IFCONS posterior odds consistent NMA model (IFs) model corresponding row. estimate 1 favors consistent NMA model. example, first row refers consistent NMA model (IFs), showing posterior model probability consistent NMA model 0.79. posterior odds 1 expected, since \[PO = \frac{f(m_{con}|\boldsymbol{y})}{f(m_{con}|\boldsymbol{y})}=\frac{0.7943}{0.7943} = 1.\] third row refers inconsistent NMA model (say \(m_{3}\)) inconsistency factor added comparisons interventions AO-CT e-CHUG, obtained multi-arm studies compare interventions AO-CT, e-CHUG BASICS. posterior odds calculated \[PO_{m_{con}m_{3}} = \frac{f(m_{con}|\boldsymbol{y})}{f(m_{3}|\boldsymbol{y})} =\frac{0.7942875}{0.0193125} = 41.1282.\] looking posterior model probabilities posterior model odds, conclude consistent NMA dominant model since \(\hat{f(m|y)}=0.79\). Also, posterior odds clearly favors consistent NMA model. Thus, conclude network globally locally consistent, significant local inconsistencies causes globally inconsistency network observed.
code: head(m$Posterior_Odds) #>                                IFs  Freq f(m|y) PO_IFCONS #> 1                           No IFs 63543 0.7943    1.0000 #> 2               Active-CT ; THRIVE  1549 0.0194   41.0219 #> 3 AO-CT ; e-CHUG_AO-CTe-CHUGBASICS  1545 0.0193   41.1282 #> 4 AO-CT ; BASICS_AO-CTe-CHUGBASICS  1519 0.0190   41.8321 #> 5 AO-CT ; AlcEdu_AO-CTAlcEdue-CHUG  1517 0.0190   41.8873 #> 6                  e-CHUG ; BASICS  1496 0.0187   42.4753

what: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of brief alcohol interventions. — Alcohol
title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of brief alcohol interventions. — Alcohol
text: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection evaluation consistency assumption network meta-analysis model. data used example Seitidis et al. (2021).

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of brief alcohol interventions. — Alcohol
text: data frame following columns:

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of brief alcohol interventions. — Alcohol
text: Seitidis G, Nikolakopoulos S, Hennessy EA, Tanner-Smith EE, Mavridis D (2021): Network Meta-Analysis Techniques Synthesizing Prevention Science Evidence Prevention Science, 1-10

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of brief alcohol interventions. — Alcohol
code: if (FALSE) { data(Alcohol)  TE <- Alcohol$TE seTE <- Alcohol$seTE studlab <- Alcohol$studyid treat1 <- Alcohol$treat2 treat2 <- Alcohol$treat1  # Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection using as reference treatment AO-CT and the # Lu & Ades method for the specification of the Z matrix.  m <- ssifs(TE, seTE, treat1, treat2, studlab, ref = "AO-CT", method = "LuAdes") }

what: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of interventions for smoking cessation — smokingcessation
title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of interventions for smoking cessation — smokingcessation
text: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection evaluation consistency assumption network meta-analysis model. data used example Dias et al. (2013).

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of interventions for smoking cessation — smokingcessation
text: data frame following columns:

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of interventions for smoking cessation — smokingcessation
text: Dias S, Welton NJ, Sutton AJ, Caldwell DM, Lu G Ades AE (2013): Evidence Synthesis Decision Making 4: Inconsistency networks evidence based randomized controlled trials. Medical Decision Making, 33, 641--56

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection of interventions for smoking cessation — smokingcessation
code: if (FALSE) { data(smokingcessation)  # Transform data from arm-based format to contrast-based format  smokingcessation$id <- 1:dim(smokingcessation)[1] smoking.pair <- netmeta::pairwise(   treat = list(treat1, treat2, treat3),   event = list(event1, event2, event3),   n = list(n1, n2, n3),   studlab = id,   data = smokingcessation,   sm = "OR" )  TE <- smoking.pair$TE seTE <- smoking.pair$seTE studlab <- smoking.pair$studlab treat1 <- smoking.pair$treat1 treat2 <- smoking.pair$treat2  # Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection using as reference treatment A and the # design-by-treatment method for the specification of the Z matrix  m <- ssifs(TE, seTE, treat1, treat2, studlab, ref = "A") }

title: Inconsistency Factors' Spike and Slab — spike.slab
text: function creates two density plots inconsistency factor based inconsistency factors' effects, obtained ssifs model. former visualizes effect inconsistency factor included NMA model (spike) latter (slab). good mixing SSIFS model indicates spike high density values close zero whereas slab flat.

title: Inconsistency Factors' Spike and Slab — spike.slab
code: if (FALSE) { data(Alcohol)  TE <- Alcohol$TE seTE <- Alcohol$seTE studlab <- Alcohol$studyid treat1 <- Alcohol$treat2 treat2 <- Alcohol$treat1  # Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection using intervention AO-CT as reference.  m <- ssifs(TE, seTE, treat1, treat2, studlab, ref = "AO-CT") spike.slab(m) }

what: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
text: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection evaluates consistency assumption Network Meta-Analysis Bayesian framework, treating inconsistency detection variable selection problem. consistency assumption evaluated locally, also globally.

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
code: ssifs(   TE,   seTE,   treat1,   treat2,   studlab,   ref,   method = "DBT",   rpcons = TRUE,   pcons = 0.5,   zellner = TRUE,   c = 3,   psi = NULL,   digits = 4,   M = 50000,   B = 10000,   n_thin = 1,   n_chains = 2,   M_pilot = 10000,   B_pilot = 2000,   n_thin_pilot = 1,   n_chains_pilot = 1 )

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
text: TE Estimate treatment effect (e.g. log odds ratio, mean difference, log hazard ratio). seTE Standard error treatment estimate. treat1 Label/Number first treatment. treat2 Label/Number second treatment. studlab Study labels. ref Reference treatment. method Method used specification inconsistency factors; Possible choices : "LuAdes" Lu & Ades model (Lu & Ades, 2006) "DBT" design--treatment method (Higgins et al., 2012) "Jackson" random-effects implementation design--treatment model (Jackson et al., 2014) rpcons "logical". TRUE, informative beta distribution Beta(157, 44) used probability consistent network. pcons Probability consistent network. zellner "logical". TRUE, Zellner g-prior used dependency inconsistency factors. FALSE, inconsistency factors assumed independent. c Tuning parameter. psi Tuning parameter. digits Digits exported results. M Number NMA MCMC iterations. B Burn-period NMA MCMC run. n_thin Thinning interval NMA MCMC run. n_chains Number parallel chains NMA MCMC run. M_pilot Number pilot MCMC iterations. B_pilot Burn-period pilot MCMC run. n_thin_pilot Thinning interval pilot MCMC run. n_chains_pilot Number parallel chains pilot MCMC run.

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
text: list containing following components: MCMC_run object class rjags containing MCMC run NMA model Bayes_Factor Bayes factor consistent NMA model inconsistent NMA model Posterior_inclusion_probabilities data.frame containing posterior inclusion probabilities inconsistency factors. Columns Comparison Design denote comparisons inconsistency factors added. argument method = "LuAdes", column Design NA, loop inconsistencies accounted. PIP estimated posterior inclusion probability, b estimated median effect  inconsistency factors, b.lb b.ub lower upper bound inconsistency factors' effect estimates,  respectively Posterior_Odds data.frame containing model posterior odds. Column IFs denotes  comparisons inconsistency factors added, Freq number times model observed  MCMC run, f(m|y) posterior model probability PO_IFCONS posterior model odds  consistent NMA model (denoted IFs) corresponding inconsistent NMA model. Summary data.frame containing summary estimates MCMC run NMA model Z_matrix data.frame containing first 3 columns treatment comparisons used  Z matrix Z matrix rest columns disconnected_studies vector studies excluded, order  connected network n_subnetworks Number sub-networks subnetworks list sub-networks original NMA data

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
text: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection (SSIFS) extension Stochastic Search Variable Selection (SSVS) (George & McCulloch, 1993) identifying inconsistencies Network Meta-Analysis (NMA). SSIFS two-step method inconsistency factors specified first step, second step, SSVS performed inconsistency factors. method used specification inconsistency factors, controlled argument method. Among choices may considered Lu Ades model (Lu & Ades, 2006), design--treatment model (Higgins et al., 2012), random-effects implementation design--treatment model (Jackson et al., 2014). specifying inconsistency factors, random-effects NMA model implemented Bayesian framework using R2jags package. uninformative normal assumed prior distribution treatment effects, heterogeneity parameter tau, uninformative half-normal assumed. function provides MCMC run NMA model (item MCMC_run), whereby user can check convergence MCMC run. SSVS, default, assumes inconsistency factors dependent Zellner g-prior used describe dependency (zellner = TRUE). Parameter g Zellner g-prior specified using unit information criterion (Kass & Wasserman, 1995), translates SSIFS total number observed comparisons network. setting argument zellner = FALSE, inconsistency factors assumed independent. Regarding inclusion probabilities, function default assumes informative Beta distribution (Beta(157, 44)) probability consistent network (rpcons = TRUE). case rpcons = FALSE, probability assumed fixed equal 0.5 (pcons = 0.5). user can modify probability argument pcons. Tunning parameters SSVS specified arguments c psi. specified way , inconsistency factor included NMA model, corresponding coefficient lies area close zero, far away area included NMA model. Regarding argument c, values 10 100 usually perform well cases. Argument psi can obtained either pilot MCMC run NMA model standard deviation inconsistency factors (psi = NULL), can set fixed -priory analyst. order evaluate consistency assumption, can examine posterior inclusion probabilities inconsistency factors (item Posterior_inclusion_probabilities) posterior model probabilities (item Posterior_Odds) posterior model odds (item Posterior_Odds) Bayes factor consistent NMA model inconsistent NMA models (item Bayes_Factor) posterior inclusion probability 0.5, example, indicates inconsistency. Also, inconsistent NMA model large posterior model probability suggests presence inconsistency. Item Bayes_Factor provides global test testing consistency assumption, calculating Bayes factor consistent NMA model (model without inconsistency factors) rest inconsistent NMA models observed MCMC run. estimate 1 favors consistent NMA model. calculation Bayes factor, inconsistent NMA models treated single model corresponding posterior model probabilities summed.

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
text: function uses random effects inverse-variance NMA model, assuming common heterogeneity different treatment comparisons, correlation different studies. Also note function keeps studies belong largest sub-network, network disconnected, order maintain one connected network. multi-arm study T comparisons, T-1 required NMA model since rest obtained linear combination. function automatically excludes unnecessary comparisons, maintaining basic comparisons (possible) comparisons inconsistency factor added (possible). Therefore, possible comparisons multi-arm studies must provided user. names inconsistency factor, treatments separated symbol " ; ". example, inconsistency factor added comparison treatments B, inconsistency factor name ; B. case method = "DBT" method = "Jackson", inconsistency factors' names multi-arm designs denoted treatment.comparison_design. Thus, inconsistency factor added comparison treatments B ABC design, inconsistency factor name ; B_ABC. extremely large networks potentially exponentially many paths two nodes, may run memory using Lu Ades model specification inconsistency factors, network lattice-like.

title: Stochastic Search Inconsistency Factor Selection — ssifs
text: George, E. ., & McCulloch, R. E. (1993): Variable selection via Gibbs sampling. Journal American Statistical Association, 88(423), 881-889. Lu, G., & Ades, . E. (2006): Assessing evidence inconsistency mixed treatment comparisons. Journal American Statistical Association, 101(474), 447-459. Higgins, J. P. T., Jackson, D., Barrett, J. K., Lu, G., Ades, . E., & White, . R. (2012): Consistency inconsistency network meta-analysis: concepts models multi-arm studies. Research synthesis methods, 3(2), 98-110. Jackson, D., Barrett, J. K., Rice, S., White, . R., & Higgins, J. P. (2014): design--treatment interaction model network meta-analysis random inconsistency effects. Statistics medicine, 33(21), 3639-3654. Kass, R. E., & Wasserman, L. (1995): Reference Bayesian Test Nested Hypotheses Relationship Schwarz Criterion. Journal American Statistical Association, 90(431), 928–934.
